name: Yarrow
description: Powerful healing and magical herb sacred to Odin. Used by Norse warriors to staunch battlefield wounds, in prophetic divination, and protection magic. Featured in Anglo-Saxon Nine Herbs Charm. Both healer and seer's ally.

mythologicalName.achillea: Named after Achilles (Greek), who used yarrow to heal warriors at Troy
mythologicalName.odinConnection: Norse warriors invoked Odin while using yarrow for wounds

uses: Battlefield medicine - Norse warriors carried yarrow to stop bleeding
Divination - yarrow stalks for rune casting and I Ching
Protection charms - dried yarrow in amulets and threshold bundles
Love magic - yarrow under pillow to dream of true love
Prophetic dreams - tea before sleep enhances visions
Seidr practice - völvas used yarrow in shamanic work
Weather magic - burned to summon or dispel storms
rituals: Nine Herbs Charm - yarrow is one of nine sacred Anglo-Saxon healing plants
Battle blessing - warriors annointed with yarrow oil before combat
Divination casting - yarrow stalks for oracles (adopted from Chinese)
Dream incubation - yarrow under pillow with petition to Odin
Threshold protection - fresh yarrow renewed weekly at doorsteps
Wedding handfasting - yarrow in bridal wreaths for lasting love
Funeral rites - yarrow placed with dead for protection in afterlife

nineHerbsCharm.text: Anglo-Saxon charm naming yarrow among nine sacred herbs against poison and infection
nineHerbsCharm.yarrowVerse: And you, Yarrow, what you made known... the mighty one sent you through the world
nineHerbsCharm.purpose: Healing wounds, expelling venom, breaking curses
nineHerbsCharm.practice: Sung while preparing herbal healing poultice

sacredSignificance: Odin's healing herb given to humanity. Viking warriors never traveled without yarrow. Völvas used in seeing work. Bridge between warrior and healer paths. Name 'Soldier's Herb' endures through medieval and modern warfare.
folkMagic: First yarrow of spring brings good luck all year
Yarrow in nose causes bleeding but attracts prophetic visions
Wedding wreaths ensure 7 years fidelity minimum
Hung above cradles to protect infants from evil eye
Yarrow wilting suddenly = death omen warning
culturalContext: Used continuously from Viking Age through WWI ('soldier's herb'). Medieval knights carried yarrow. Chinese I Ching divination uses 50 yarrow stalks. Pan-cultural healing plant. Modern herbalists still use for wounds and fever.
preparationMethods: Fresh poultice: crush leaves, apply directly to wounds (stops bleeding)
Yarrow tea: 1-2 tsp dried flowers in hot water for fevers, colds, digestion
Tincture: alcohol extract for long-term storage and potent medicine
Infused oil: soak flowers in oil for topical wound treatment
Salve: combine infused oil with beeswax for healing balm
Divination stalks: dry 50 stems cut to uniform length
Protective bundles: dried flowers tied with red thread, hung in home
Smoke cleansing: burn dried yarrow to purify sacred spaces
Dream pillow: sew dried yarrow into small cloth pouch, place under pillow

growingConditions.invasive: Can become weedy - easy to grow

symbolicMeanings: Feathery leaves = connection to spirit realm
Pink/red varieties = warrior courage and blood
Bitter taste = hard truths and necessary medicine
safetyWarnings: generally safe for traditional herbal use
long-term internal use may cause photosensitivity
